In arriving at a decision in this case it is necessary in the first place to consider in detail the relevant provisions of the Foreign Jurisdiction (Probates) Order in Council 1908. Article 5 (l) provides for the affidavit with which the person applying for prehate or administration must accompa his14 - 17 his application* Article 5(2) provides for corrections in the original affidavit being made by a further affidavit, to be sworn by the person who applied for the grant of probate or administration* Article 9 provides that the Court may obtain further information, by affidavit or otherwise, regarding the estate from any person, or may direct enquiries concerning it, and then goes on 'the information or report so received shall be rt deemed to be a portion of the affidavit of the applicant *for probate or letters of administration - . Finally, Article 15 lays it down that where a further affidavit is sworn under Article 5(2), and the Court is satisfied either that a larger fee or a smaller fee should have been paid on the grant of probate or administration,the Court may direct a further fee to be paid as may be due, or may direct such sum to be repaid to the applicant as may seem jUSto That is to say, it is only when a further affidavit correcting an error in the first affidavit is made by the person who applied for probate or administration, and to whom a grant of probate or administration has issued, that Article 13 comes into operation. To give any other meaning to Article 1 3 is to reduce the first line of that article to anullity, and as was said by Jessell M.R« in Yorkshire Insurance Company v. Clayton (1881), 8 at p.424. 'Although it may not always be possible to give 'a meaning to every word used in an Act of 'Parliament, it is a general rule that it is 'right not to treat word surplusage if a meaning 'can be fairly given to them'. The same canon of interpretation of course applies also to legis lative enactments by His Majesty in Council. By treating the words in Article 13 'where a further 'affidavit is sworn under Article 5(2)' as presenting a condition precedsnt upon the fulfilment of which alone the remainderremainder of the article can he held to operate, we can fairly give a meaning to the article, which, it must not he forgotten, is concerned with the revenues of the Grown and is therefore a legislative instrument which calls for a strict interpretation* This being so, I am hound to hold that Article 13 is not applicable in the circumstances of the present case and that the appeal on behalf of Gabriel Shama must succeed. mods.abstract: The file concerns the issue by the Foreign Office of the Foreign Jurisdiction (Probates) Order in Council, 1935, and its application to, and publication in, Bahrain.The date range gives the dates of the earliest document in the file (an enclosure on folio 20) and last dated addition to the file (an entry in the notes on folio 31); the covering dates of the main run of correspondence are 17 February-15 August 1935.
